children.subject: If you took 106 over FA 2020 or SP 2021, I can understand this view although the course still had a significant simulation lab component. Even then, 60% of your grade comes from lab + final project. And now the homeworks have significant programming components as well. The math in the class is very dense, but we are trying hard to not make the class feel like a math class, although we can definitely do better in that area!

history.content:
EECS 106A is mandatory if you want to do anything in robotics. Highly recommend that class over any other. 106A is lab heavy and doesn't use anything from 16B other than basic linear algebra.

If you like tinkering, you may be more interested in mechatronics EE 192, which is a lab class, and some classes from the mechanical engineering department.

EECS 106B continues off of 106A, is very lab heavy and very research focused.

If you view EECS 106A/B as classical robotics courses, then CS 287 is a more modern robotics course with emphasis on optimization, probability, and learning. Not to say that 106 material is "outdated" (loosely, it's like the split between model-based vs model-free methods). 106 definitely has more of a lab focus!

EECS 149 is the embedded systems course and is much lower level than 106. I like to view 106 as what you can do when you have a nice Python/C interface for your robot and can do more high-level manipulation. 149 is about actually constructing that nice Python/C interface for your hardware (ex. writing C code to implement Arduino library functions). The course is pretty lab heavy and has some pretty cool CS theory as well.

EE 128 isn't necessarily a robotics course, but has an interesting lab if you take it in person and the knowledge you gain will be pretty useful for your future robotics career!

If you like tinkering, you may be more interested in mechatronics EE 192, which is a lab class, and some classes from the mechanical engineering department.

EECS 106A is mandatory if you want to do anything in robotics. Highly recommend that class over any other.

I'm possibly interested in robotics after doing 16B and was wondering what classes to look into based on what I would learn/ build from them.

I don't anticipate having much room in my schedule for too many robotics classes, so that's why I'm interested in prioritizing them based on what the more rewarding tinkering experiences are. I am leaning towards a bioengineering focus, so applicability in that area is a plus.

I've heard of EECS 106, but because of the lack of the 16B prereq, I wonder if it will be a repeat of 16B in terms of tinkering. Should I take 106 before I go into any other robotics classes as it is the "intro to robotics"?

Also, are there any lab-heavy robotics classes that are worth taking? I don't really understand much from course names and descriptions to tell how important or interesting they are.

Thanks in advance!!
history.subject: Robotics courses and their differences?
